Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Computing Cluster for Portland Institute for Computational Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research enterprise acquires, deploys, and maintains a modern heterogeneous cluster for scientific computing. The cluster combines the latest multi-core processors with the new MIC (Many Integrated Core) architecture to provide a testbed for development of new parallel mathematical algorithms. Multi-institutional access to the equipment, managed through a new center called the Portland Institute for Computational Sciences, will catalyze interactions within a regional user base of computational scientists. This equipment will considerably strengthen open, state-wide high performance computing access in Oregon.

The equipment aims to profoundly impact research into fundamentally new techniques in computational mathematics. Highly scalable dimension reduction techniques that exploit existing parallelization tools developed at US national laboratories will be designed for evolution problems posed in spacetime domains. For hyperbolic problems on complex spacetime structures, a new class of mathematically sound methods, well-suited for thread parallelism on MICs, will be studied. New algorithms to compute eigenmodes of partial differential operators, based on parallelizable approximations of operator-valued contour integrals, are considered. Another project will use massive medical data sets to validate novel statistical inferential methods leading to valuable templates of disease progression. The equipment will be extensively used to develop and run numerical simulations of convection in Earth's mantle. Further catalogued examples of projects show that the equipment's impact will be regional and beyond Oregon. Educational and training activities will promote the learning of fine-grained parallelism critical to exploit new and emerging energy-efficient processors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant enabled the acquisition and deployment of a medium-scale high performance computing cluster, the creation of accompanying user support mechanisms, and the establishment of a synergistic center for computational enquiry.  The center, called Portland Institute for Computational Science (PICS), manages free multi-institutional access to the cluster. At the conclusion of the grant, PICS had over 200 members with free access to the equipment, not just from the grantee institution (Portland State University), but also from others (such as Lewis & Clark College, Oregon Health & Science University, Oregon State University, Reed College, University of Oregon, University of California Davis, and Washington State University).

Computational advances made possible by the equipment include new numerical methods for simulation of waves, including parallel spacetime discretizations, new eigensolvers with multiple layers of parallelism, and finite elements on curvilinear meshes.  Numerous advances in scientific domains outside of computational mathematics were enabled by the equipment, such as simulation of changes in the structure of Earth's mantle over geologic time, models of trajectories of neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's, maps of internal ocean waves from remotely-sensed data, and beam propagation in optical fiber amplifiers.

Researchers with access to the equipment include professors, scientists from government labs, postdoctoral associates, graduate students and undergraduate students. Educational and training materials to ease introduction to supercomputer usage, particularly for students, were developed as part of this grant. Since the lifetime of the equipment is projected to be beyond the duration of the grant, the equipment will continue to be maintained and used by a diverse group of scientists.
